StratMap20010920Texas Cultural BoundariesAustin, TXTexas Natural Resources Information System Series Information: Series Name: Texas Political Boundaries Issue Identification: First generation statewide coverage PUBLIC_LAND.STRAT_OTHER_POLYvector digital data\\TSD-JJOHN-2\D$\Documents and Settings\JJOHN\Desktop\TNRIS.gdbThe statewide Texas boundary dataset is one component of the Texas Strategic Mapping Program (StratMap). The StratMap program developed seven digital base map, or layers for Texas. StratMap is managed by the Texas Natural Resources Information System (TNRIS), a division of the Texas Water Development Board (TWDB). All data produced through StratMap are available in the public domain.Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.1.0.722enThe statewide Texas boundary dataset is one component of the Texas Strategic Mapping Program (StratMap). The StratMap program developed seven digital base map, or layers for Texas. StratMap is managed by the Texas Natural Resources Information System (TNRIS), a division of the Texas Water Development Board (TWDB). All data produced through StratMap are available in the public domain. The StratMap boundary dataset produced files corresponding to multi-county councils of government across Texas as well as a statewide dataset. Each boundary file has five themes including state, county, city, parks, and other (i.e. federal lands, landmarks, country clubs). The data sources for each council of government coverage vary but could include digital orthophoto quads (DOQs), USGS digital raster graphics (DRGs), Texas Department of Transportation data, and local data from the council of governments or its component governments. The attribute coding scheme is designed to accommodate several basic cartographic data categories such as feature type, feature name, jurisdiction entity, data source used in feature collection, data source date and revision date(s) if applicable.This data is suitable for general planning purposes. Inconsistencies between data sources were not always resolved and in some cases features which should be co-existent will be represented by several contradictory lines.ground condition1997CompleteIrregular-106.596033-93.75012936.42322925.840805-106.596033-93.75012925.84080536.423229State boundariescounty boundariesstate boundarypark boundariesBoundariesTexasTXNoneStratMap does not warrant this data for any particular use and is not responsible for any damages resulting from the use of the data. Users of these files should be aware that (1) StratMap data are not authoritative representations of legal boundaries, (2) StratMap boundary lines are subject to change and corrections, (3) StratMap boundaries were generated from the best available data which are subject to change, and (4) StratMap is updating boundary data and has a process for collecting and noting boundary changes. Contact StratMap for more details. Acknowledgement of the StratMap program and Titan Systems Corp.,is appreciated in products derived and used from these data.SDE Feature ClassUnclassifiedSee Entity_Attribute_InformationSee ExplanationAttribute accuracy is described, where present, with each attribute defined in the Entity and Attribute Section.Polygon and chain-node topology present.This process step outlines the general data hierarchy used for producing boundary data for the Texas Strategic Mapping Program (StratMap). Each dataset's position in the data hierarchy is determined by its spatial and temporal accuracy. Spatial accuracy is the difference between a dataset's georeferenced location and the dataset's true location. Temporal accuracy refers to how current the dataset is. For county and state boundaries, only the DRG dataset was used. For the municipal boundaries local data was used if supplied, otherwise the municipality was derived from the TxDOT DGN area files (temporally accurate) and revised to DRG files (spatially correct). In this case only entire polygons were moved to a best fit\rdblquote of the DRG, individual vertices were not manipulated. Only non-contiguous polygons were moved in this manner. County and state boundary polygons contiguous with other county and state polygons were left alone. For the parks and other\rdblquote boundaries the polygons were derived from TxDOT DGN area files when supplied and updated to the DOQQs. In this case vertices were moved to fit the DOQQ. If no TxDOT DGN area file was supplied the polygon was heads-up digitized from the DOQQ. The TxDOT County Maps of Texas: 1998\rdblquote and corresponding map sheets were used to identify features to capture when not provided in digital format. Digitize county and state boundaries using 1:24,000 scale seamless DRGs obtained from the National Resource Conservation Service (NRCS) as a background. Digitizing was performed by tracing over boundaries in a heads up\rdblquote manner, not by using a digitizing tablet.d:\Temp\xml21.tmp2004040611573700U.S. Geological Survey, reprocessed by Beartooth Mapping and the Natural Resources and Conservation Service.1999Dataset copied.Server=COMANCHE; Service=sde_COMANCHE; Database=ISD; User=ISD; Version=ISD.ISD_GIS2004110110504100Dataset copied.Server=apache; Service=sde_apache; User=public_land; Version=SDE.DEFAULT2004110119001500Dataset copied.Server=Tarhe; Service=sde:oracle10g; User=mstuser; Version=SDE.DEFAULT2011120609252300The multiple boundary layers were visually inspected and compared to source maps by a second technician to ensure reasonable horizontal position accuracy. Where necessary, areas were plotted at larger scales to aid visual inspection of detailed areas of the data set.Data photorevised to the DOQQs: +/-10 meters. Data revised to the DRGs: +/- 12 meters.Resolution as reported.VectorSimpleFALSE1515FALSEFALSEDecimal DegreesGCS_North_American_1983Decimal degrees0.0000000.000000North American Datum of 1983Geodetic Reference System 806378137.000000298.257222North American Datum of 1983GRS19806378206.4294.98Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates1.000000StratMap_Cultural_v3Feature Class1515FIDFIDOID400Internal feature number.ESRISequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.JURISDCTNJURISDCTNString3000TYPETYPEString3000SOURCESOURCEString1600NAMENAMEString8000SHAPEShapeGeometry000Feature geometry.ESRICoordinates defining the features.DATE_CREATDATE_CREATString2000DATE_MODIFDATE_MODIFString2000DATE_PUBDATE_PUBString1000SOURCE_LEVSOURCE_LEVString5000Not AvailableTxDOT512-465-7668ISD-GIS-Supoort@dot.state.tx.usDownloadable Data1997 The StratMap boundary dataset produced files corresponding to multi-county councils of government across Texas as well as a statewide dataset. Each boundary file has five themes including state, county, city, parks, and other (i.e. federal lands, landmarks, country clubs). The data sources for each council of government coverage vary but could include digital orthophoto quads (DOQs), USGS digital raster graphics (DRGs), Texas Department of Transportation data, and local data from the council of governments or its component governments. The attribute coding scheme is designed to accommodate several basic cartographic data categories such as feature type, feature name, jurisdiction entity, data source used in feature collection, data source date and revision date(s) if applicable. This data is suitable for general planning purposes. Inconsistencies between data sources were not always resolved and in some cases features which should be co-existent will be represented by several contradictory lines. This is most readily apparent where municipal and county boundaries should correspond but do not due to different sources of the input data. Please see Process Step #1 for more information on how differences between data sources were handled.2002040820010920CompleteIrregular-106.646-93.50836.50028.837State boundariescounty boundariesstate boundarypark boundariesKeyword: BoundariesTexasTXNoneAccess_Constraints None StratMap does not warrant this data for any particular use and is not responsible for any damages resulting from the use of the data. Users of these files should be aware that (1) StratMap data are not authoritative representations of legal boundaries, (2) StratMap boundary lines are subject to change and corrections, (3) StratMap boundaries were generated from the best available data which are subject to change, and (4) StratMap is updating boundary data and has a process for collecting and noting boundary changes. Contact StratMap for more details. Acknowledgement of the StratMap program and Titan Systems Corp.,is appreciated in products derived and used from these data. Texas Natural Resources Information System Mailing addressP O Box 13231AustinTX78711-3231USA512-463-8337512-463-7274request@tnris.state.tx.us0730 - 1730 Monday-Friday CSTTitan Systems CorporationNoneUnclassifiedNoneWindows_NT, 4.0, Intel NT, ARC/INFO version 7.2.1 This data set includes polygonal representation of physical and political boundary data for the State of Texas. The data has been subdivided and delivered based on each of the 24 Texas Councils of Government (COGs). The multiple boundary layers were visually inspected and compared to source maps by a second technician to ensure reasonable horizontal position accuracy. Where necessary, areas were plotted at larger scales to aid visual inspection of detailed areas of the data set. Data photorevised to the DOQQs: +/-10 meters. Data revised to the DRGs: +/- 12 meters. Resolution as reported. U.S. Geological Survey, reprocessed by Beartooth Mapping and the Natural Resources and Conservation Service. Digital Raster Graphic (DRG)24,000digital file Texas Orthoimagery Program (TOP) and U.S. Geological Survey Digital Ortho Quarter Quad (DOQQ)1:12,000digital fileSource_ContributionTexas Department of Transportation20000823-20001110Design File (DGN) TxDOT Area files24,000digital fileSource_Contribution Process Step: Process Description: This process step outlines the general data hierarchy used for producing boundary data for the Texas Strategic Mapping Program (StratMap). Each dataset's position in the data hierarchy is determined by its spatial and temporal accuracy. Spatial accuracy is the difference between a dataset's georeferenced location and the dataset's true location. Temporal accuracy refers to how current the dataset is. For county and state boundaries, only the DRG dataset was used. For the municipal boundaries local data was used if supplied, otherwise the municipality was derived from the TxDOT DGN area files (temporally accurate) and revised to DRG files (spatially correct). In this case only entire polygons were moved to a best fit\rdblquote of the DRG, individual vertices were not manipulated. Only non-contiguous polygons were moved in this manner. County and state boundary polygons contiguous with other county and state polygons were left alone. For the parks and other\rdblquote boundaries the polygons were derived from TxDOT DGN area files when supplied and updated to the DOQQs. In this case vertices were moved to fit the DOQQ. If no TxDOT DGN area file was supplied the polygon was heads-up digitized from the DOQQ. The TxDOT County Maps of Texas: 1998\rdblquote and corresponding map sheets were used to identify features to capture when not provided in digital format. Digitize county and state boundaries using 1:24,000 scale seamless DRGs obtained from the National Resource Conservation Service (NRCS) as a background. Digitizing was performed by tracing over boundaries in a heads up\rdblquote manner, not by using a digitizing tablet. Create city coverage. Use local data if available (Houston was the only local data provided). Adjacent city polygons were merged to local data polygons (Houston). Surrounding polygons were converted from TxDOT area files. The locally supplied data was not moved. In the case local data was unavailable, shapefiles were converted from TxDOT DGN files levels 10-20 into shapefile format. These levels correspond to feature classes 10 - void areas, 11-20 municipal areas. Convert shapefile into ArcInfo regions coverage. Create park coverage. Convert shapes from TxDOT DGN files levels 22, 24, 25, 32, 48, 53, and 54 into shapefile format. These levels correspond to feature classes County Park, state park, national park, amusement park, forest, park, City Park, respectively. Revise boundaries to DOQQs. Convert shapefile into ArcInfo regions coverage. Generate other\rdblquote coverage. Convert shapes from TxDOT DGN files levels 21, 23, 26, 27, 29, 30, 31, and 49, into shapefile format. These levels correspond to feature classes: These levels correspond to feature classes airport, military base, country club/golf course, university/state school, wildlife management area, national grassland, mental health mental retardation (mhmr), airport, respectively. Revise boundaries to DOQQs. Convert shapefile into ArcInfo regions coverage. Inconsistencies between data sources were not always resolved and in some cases features which should be co-existent will be represented by several contradictory lines.

The statewide Texas cultural boundary dataset is one component of the Texas Strategic Mapping Program (StratMap). The StratMap program developed seven digital base map, or layers for Texas. StratMap is managed by the Texas Natural Resources Information System (TNRIS), a division of the Texas Water Development Board (TWDB). All data produced through StratMap are available in the public domain. The StratMap boundary dataset produced files corresponding to multi-county councils of government across Texas as well as a statewide dataset. Each boundary file has five themes including state, county, city, parks, and other (i.e. federal lands, landmarks, country clubs). The data sources for each council of government coverage vary but could include digital orthophoto quads (DOQs), USGS digital raster graphics (DRGs), Texas Department of Transportation data, and local data from the council of governments or its component governments. The attribute coding scheme is designed to accommodate several basic cartographic data categories such as feature type, feature name, jurisdiction entity, data source used in feature collection, data source date and revision date(s) if applicable.

CulturalPlaceBoundaries

StratMap does not warrant this data for any particular use and is not responsible for any damages resulting from the use of the data. Users of these files should be aware that (1) StratMap data are not authoritative representations of legal boundaries, (2) StratMap boundary lines are subject to change and corrections, (3) StratMap boundaries were generated from the best available data which are subject to change, and (4) StratMap is updating boundary data and has a process for collecting and noting boundary changes. Contact StratMap for more details. Acknowledgement of the StratMap program and TxDOTare appreciated in products derived and used from these data.
